Release 0.4.3

[jdbc] Upgrade clojure.java.jdbc to 0.6.1

This commit updates clojure.java.jdbc to 0.6.1. This update is important
in that it also addresses a number of cases in which features have not
only been deprecated but officially dropped in the 0.6.x branch.

clojure.java.jdbc includes a call to `reduce-kv`, which was introduced in
Clojure 1.4.0. This means that it is not compatible with Clojure 1.3.0 or
earlier.
Update c3p0 version to com.mchange/c3p0 0.9.5.2
supprot predicate keyword
Update entity-fields documentation
Clojure 1.8

Make order of values for insert queries not matter

So that the two following queries insert the same data:

  (insert users
          (values [{:first "icarus"}
                   {:first "chris" :last "granger"}]))

  (insert users
          (values [{:first "chris" :last "granger"}
                   {:first "icarus"}]))

[jdbc] Upgrade clojure.java.jdbc to 0.6.1

This commit updates clojure.java.jdbc to 0.6.1. This update is important
in that it also addresses a number of cases in which features have not
only been deprecated but officially dropped in the 0.6.x branch.

clojure.java.jdbc includes a call to `reduce-kv`, which was introduced in
Clojure 1.4.0. This means that it is not compatible with Clojure 1.3.0 or
earlier.

Implemented support for composite primary keys and composite foreign keys for the following relationship types: with-one, belongs-to, has-many, many-to-many, with-batch.

Release 0.4.1

Pass driver properties to connection pool

This allows setting JDBC driver properties in the same way whether connection pool is in use or not.

There is no need to set user and password separately, they are included in the properties and are read from there.

It is not strictly necessary to dissoc irrelevant keys when setting connection pool properties.

Merge pull request #283 from juhovh/fix-relation-namespace

Fix lazy namespace resolution of relations.

Fix lazy namespace resolution of relations.

Earlier the relations used lazy entity resolving from the current namespace, but
they should be resolve the entity from the original namespace instead. Otherwise
it is possible that if an entity is in a different namespace than where it is
used, it fails to resolve the referred entities.

This test was executed as a first test of korma.core.test prior to Clojure 1.6. This caused other tests to incorrectly pass.

Ensure correct default connection

I think tests are supposed to use connection set by last defdb call. However, because all test namespaces are loaded before tests are executed, the last defdb call is made in another namespace.

This problem was not visible before running test with Clojure 1.6 which changed the test execution order.

Bump version to 0.3.1-SNAPSHOT.
Merge branch 'clean-up-project.clj'

Extract common JDBC-connector dependencies.

Even if you run `lein with-profile 1.3 test`, the `:test` profile (and
its associated dependencies!) are merged into the project map, so we
don't need to worry about creating, e.g., a test profile for Clojure
1.3, a test profile for Clojure 1.4, a test profile for Clojure 1.5, etc.

Oh, and I'm just gambling that Postgres and Criterium really are meant
as dev-dependencies and not test-dependencies.

Remove redundant dependencies on `java.jdbc`.

Even if you specify to Leiningen that you _only_ want a certain profile
activated —e.g., `lein with-profile 1.3 …`— the top-level dependencies
are still merged in.

Drop the patch-num from the version profile names.

It seemed distasteful to me to have a profile named `:1.5.0` and yet
have Clojure 1.5.*1* be under test. Just to be consistent,
I changed `:1.4.0` and `:1.3.0` too.

Commit to Leiningen 2. Remove `:dev-dependencies`.

Each of jars listed under the (“Lein1-style”) `:dev-dependencies` is
already present in the (“Lein2-style”) `:dev` profile’s `:dependencies`
vector.

Remove improper (and redundant) `:user` deps.

Justification
=============

The dependencies listed in the `:user` profile are the same
dependencies listed for “Lein1”.

We’re *supposed* to leave `:user` outta `project.clj`.
------------------------------------------------------

Using Leiningen 2.3.4, I see the following message printed before any
task: “WARNING: user-level profile defined in project files.”

Also, the documentation explicitly clarifies the role of the `:user` profile:

> The `:user` profile is separate from `:dev`; the latter is intended to
> be specified in the project itself. In order to avoid collisions, the
> project should never define a `:user` profile, nor should a user-wide
> `:dev` profile be defined.

Top-level `:dependencies` aren’t bad.
-------------------------------------

In fact, they’re still used in Leiningen’s own project files.

- https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/2.3.4/project.clj#L9
- https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/2.3.4/sample.project.clj#L45

Bite the bullet and release version 0.3.0.

Merge pull request #130 from josephwilk/master

Bug: Nested transactions deadlock with MYSQL.

Support nested transactions with MYSQL.
If you are in a nested transaction you already have a connection open. Trying to open another connection will block and error with: java.sql.SQLException: Lock wait timeout exceeded; try restarting transaction.
Instead test if there is a connection already open and don't open another if there is one present.

Merge pull request #58 from RingMan/paren-joins

Parenthesize multiple JOIN expressions

Parenthesize multiple JOIN expressions

Microsoft Access complains about syntax errors when using
multiple joins.  The solution seems to be wrapping nested
joins in parentheses.

Example:

(use '[korma config core])
(defentity users)
(defentity emails)
(defentity phones)
(set-delimiters "[" "]")
(def q (-> (select* users)
         (join emails (= :users.email :email.addr))
         (join phones (= :users.phone :phone.num))))
(sql-only (select q))

SELECT [users].*
FROM ([users]
      LEFT JOIN [emails] ON [users].[email] = [email].[addr])
      LEFT JOIN [phones] ON [users].[phone] = [phone].[num]

Merge pull request #117 from RingMan/not-equal

Use <> instead of != in relational comparisons

Use <> instead of != in relational comparisons

Using this form of comparison allows Microsoft Access queries
that test for inequality to use the normal predicate syntax
instead of calling the 'raw' function. I believe <> is valid
generic SQL and still works with all the other vendors.

Merge pull request #95 from benburkert/master

Transform database results on all queries that return results.

Return the same type of transformed results.

The results may be a vector or a map, but the transformed type should be
consistent.
Fix transform function calls.
Call transform function on all but delete queries.
Add a test for the prepare functionality.
A test for a spec one might use within an app server

Only create a connection pool if the spec has the necessary data.

Otherwise, return the spec, as it could represent a DataSource that is
already pooled, possibly referenced by a JNDI name. We want to get the
benefits from the korma api for those kinds of connection specs as
well.

Also, we no longer assume a spec has a :pool entry, though we'll use
it if it does.

Merge the defaults instead of overwrite them.

This is particularly important when connection specs include enough to
obtain a connection but not enough to create a c3p0 pool, i.e. when
the spec doesn't include an :options entry.

Merge pull request #61 from felideon/fix-handle-exception

Make handle-exception a bit more robust

Make handle-exception a bit more robust

Reason for this change is that getNextException may return null, so we
don't want to always call that on every SQL exception. The cond got a
bit messy when adding this new condition, and it only had two branches
to begin with.
